questions.question: What is the most popular distributed version control system?
questions.explanation: Git is the most widely used version control system, created by Linus Torvalds in 2005.

questions.question: What command creates a new branch in Git?
questions.explanation: The git branch command creates a new branch, allowing independent development lines.

questions.question: What operation combines changes from one branch into another?
questions.explanation: Merging integrates changes from one branch into another branch.

questions.question: What operation rewrites commits onto a new base?
questions.explanation: Rebase moves or combines commits to create a linear history.

questions.question: What is a request to merge changes from one branch to another?
questions.explanation: Pull Requests let you notify team members about changes ready for review and merging.

questions.question: What occurs when two branches modify the same code differently?
questions.explanation: Merge conflicts happen when Git cannot automatically resolve differences between branches.

questions.question: What command temporarily saves uncommitted changes?
questions.explanation: git stash saves your modified tracked files temporarily so you can switch branches cleanly.

questions.question: What creates a named reference to a specific commit?
questions.explanation: Tags mark specific points in history, typically used for release versions.

questions.question: What command creates a local copy of a remote repository?
questions.explanation: git clone downloads a complete copy of a repository including all history.

questions.question: What is the default branch name in most Git repositories?
questions.explanation: main is the modern default branch name, though master was historically used.
